SCRIMMAGE: Veteran Ranger Bill Moe hurdles the stick of newcomer Frank Ed
Even Coach Frank Boucher of
the Rangers can't answer that
one. It takes skill, speed and
training — and something more
The New York Rangers’ hottest forward
line is a blend of two wingmen who used to
fight every time they met on the ice, and a
center who has to be convinced that he wants
to play hockey.
The moral here is that you can never be sure
what makes a hockey player or what puts a
winning combination on ice. The Rangers’
mononror tTiwinh _
most but even he has his troubles. For the
manager of an ice-hockey team is probably
the only coach in sports who can’t tell his
players how to perform. He knows what they
should do and he can sense what they might do.
But a high-speed hockey game just doesn’t
give him time to say how or when to do it.
Despite the harassment# of his job,
Boucher remains an amiable and philo
sophic gentleman. He left the Royal Cana
dian Mounted Police 26 years ago to become a
hockey pro and he knows what to expect.
“There’s no use trying to plan your game
from the sidelines,’’ he says. "A hockey player
has a woman’s prerogative: he can change his
mind as often as he likes. He can go anywhere
on the rink that he thinks offers him a soorin
chance. All I can do is hope that he’s right -
and that he gets there fast.”
Of course, Boucher can influence the gam
by rotating his players skillfully, by spottin
technical errors for them to correct or by notin
opponents’ weaknesses for them to exploi
But the course and conduct of the game is i
the hands of the 15 free-thinking individua
who make up the Ranger squad.
It follows that Boucher can avoid a numbc
of headaches during the National Hocke
League season by picking his players carefull
at the Rangers’ training camp in the fall. Hei
he can mix old Rangers with new ones and loo
for the marks of the big leaguer among the rav
eager youngsters from Moose Jaw and Saski
toon, from Cobalt and Chicoutimi.
Picking His Men
The training schedule he sets for his clul
however, is simplicity itself: the players lac
on their skates and play hockey. There are n
calisthenics, no obstacle courses, no series c
plays to run through. Hockey people belie\
that skating is the best unlimbering exercis
and that scrimmages are the best conditioner
In making his choices, Boucher relies prett
heavily on his own observation of a player
abilities. Hockey has few statistical yardstick
that enable you to compare one man with ar
other. All that the records show is how man

LINDSAY, No. 7, hurtles after puck
in slam-bong battle with Rangers
DETROIT NEWS PHOTOS
“Cocky Kid”
(See Front Cover)
by Adie Suehsdorf
Detroit's Ted Lindsay is
a terrific hockey player
right now — what will he
be when he grows up?
Even if you don’t know anything about
ice hockey, it’s a fair bet that before
the winter is over you will have heard of the
unsmiling young man on this page.
He is Robert Blake Theodore Lindsay, of
the Detroit Red Wings, who are seen on
This Week’s cover defending their goal
against a New York Ranger attack. Lindsay,
a cocky little sprout of 23, is the best left
the majority of hockey players shoot from
the left side, and the most sensible of them
can’t give you a sensible reason for it.
Ted’s job as a left wing is to score goals
and to keep the enemy right wing, who plays
opposite him, from scoring. Anything else
he does is pretty much his own idea. A
classic example of embroidering on the
basic pattern was the game in which the
Detroit people first scouted him.
"Ha's fox Us"
Lindsay was then playing junior hockey
around Toronto. His team invaded a
small town near by and lost, 5-3. Lindsay
scored all his club’s goals, and also engaged
wing in professional hockey.
On a team which has a star at
every position, he stands out
like a misspelled word in Web
ster’s, and already, hockey men
are predicting he will take
his place with Morenz, Shore,
Boucher and the rest as a
hockey immortal.
Skilled and Rough
This is a heady draught of
greatness for a youth in his
fifth year as a pro. But it seems
warranted, mostly because Ted
Three goals + three
fights = one job
in three rights with opponents
and at game’s end was ready
to take on the officials and the
assembled citizenry. “This is
the boy for us,” said the
Detroit scout.
It must be said that there
is little of the romantic
sports hero about Lindsay.
He is no humorist, no grand
stander and he collects a lot of
penalties for rough play.
"The second year I was up,”
he chuckles, “I started to give
Richard the business one night
in Montreal.” One does not
Lindsay plays the new-style
hockey in the old-fashioned way. in a game
which old-timers insist has lost its finesse.
Ted displays the stem hockey virtues:
nimble skating, deft stick-handling, a
precise shot, stamina and a general
truculence toward opponents.
Like almost all of his colleagues, he is
Canadian-born. He is also right-handed and
can’t explain why he should be a left wing.
Lefties in hockey, as in baseball or golf, get
the power into their shots with the left hand.
And proportionally there aren’t any more
natural lefties in hockey than elsewhere in
the human race. But the fact remains that
heckle the Canadiens’ great and excitable
Maurice ‘‘The Rocket” Richard with im
punity. ‘‘I hooked and slashed him until he
finally dropped his stick and swung at me.
If I hadn’t ducked I’d still be up in the
rafters. I guess I was a cocky kid.”
Now, although hardly an old man, he is
letting up on extra-curricular activities. Jack
Adams, the salty majordomo of Detroit
hockey, warns him earnestly, "You gotta cut
out the chippy stuff now. When you first came
up, Richard was the star and you were trying
to cover him. Now he’s trying to coyer you."
There is a difference. Ask Richard.

In the drowsy comfort of his bed, John smoked... as he read his evening paper
... never expecting that he himself would be in tomorrow's headlines.
But sleep overtook him. The cigarette dropped from his hand. And, within
minutes. Fire—the Fifth Horseman—was riding again.
The enveloping flames,generating a poison
ous gas. killed him before he had even a
fighting chance to escape...
Careless smoking habits and careless use
of matches cause 240,000 fires every year!
Fire has joined the Four Horsemen—War,
Famine, Pestilence and Death! It claims
close to 12,000 lives every year!
How can you halt this killer?
1. Chaperon your cigarette—don’t let it go
out alone.
2. Put every match out cold. Keep live
ones out of reach of children.
3. Avoid improper use of gasoline and
benzine for home cleaning.
4. Use only electric wiring and appli
ances bearing the Underwriters’ Labo
ratories seal. Don’t overload circuits.
5. Maintain your furnace and stove in
good repair—and insulate them.
Follow these simple rules and I
you'll help stop 3 out of every 4 /
fires before they start. /

IT ORIGINATED IN CANADA, BUT HAS BECOME POPULAR IN AMERI
CAN CITIES—A GAME FOR THE ICE.
Hockey is in season once more. Its
votaries have grown to such large
numbers that it is plain the game has
taken its place permanently among the
standard American winter sports. Its
popularity 1« due in a large measure to
the fact that it combines all the ex
citing elements and features of such
games as football, lacrosse and polo with
the picturesque effect the players make

by being on skates. Hockey means con- '
stant action from start to finish and the
play is always open, so that even the un
initiated spectotor can keep track of it at
all times. i
To play it requires not only much
skill with the hockey stick, but a thor
ough mastery of the art of skating as
well. The hockey player must be able
to accomplish all kinds of quick move
ments, sudden stops and body balancing
on skates as effectively as if he were
playing tennis on the turf. Thus it is
that falls are few among the crack
hockey players, and it is seldom that
a serious accident happens in a hockey
match.
TEAM WORK ESSENTIAL. |
Hockey teams consist of seven play- ;
ers each, their functions being similar
to those of football or lacrosse players. '
There are forwards for offensive work, 1
cover players for defensive play and
backing up and a goal keeper to guard
that Important station. The play is es
sentially team work, although individual
achievements frequently help along to
ward victory and success. The clubs that
win often are those that do the best team
work.
The game is played on the ice, the
bone of contention being a hard rubber
puck, shaped like a two-pound weight, 1
three inches in diameter and one inch
thick. This is propelled with hockey
sticks of the shape familiar to all who
played "shinney" in their boyhood.
Hockey players become so proficient in
the use of the stick that they can push
the puck along gently, snap it in any
direction or lift it the length of the rink
by different wrist motions, according to
the demands of the moment. The object
of the play is to get the puck through the
opponents' goal.
OLD-FASHIONED SHINNEY. J
In many respects hockey is the most
attractive of all the games that have
been developed from the old-fashioned

first, and it was taken up in short order
all over that colony. While spasmodic
attempts have been made at different
times to introduce hockey in American
cities as much as fifteen years ago. it
was not until the winter of 1894-5 that
any consistent effort was made to show
Americans what real hockey was like.

FACING OFF.
Kingston, Ont., made a tour of Boston,
Pittsburg and other American cities, giv
ing exhibitions that aroused public in
terest and resulted in the establishment
of hockey teams in those cities.
New York had no ice skating rink at
the time, and could not, therefore, ac
commodate the Canadians. But it was
in New York that the first regular
hockey club was organized. About a
score of young Canadian-born residents
established the Hockey club of New York
in December, 1895, setting an example
which has been followed in nearly all the
larger eastern cities of the United States.
The Shamrock and Montreal Athletic as
sociation teams visited New York that
winter, and helped the game along by
giving clever exhibtions.
RAPID DEVELOPMENT.
About the only American dub the
Hockey club of New York could find
that winter to compete with was the
Baltimore Hockey club. The following
winter the big athletic clubs and the col
leges took the game up with such success
that it is now a part of the regular sport
ing curriculum of those institutions. The
New York Athletic club gathered in the
best seven players of the Hockey club,
not an unusual proceeding for the Mer
cury Foot ; the Knickerbockers developed
a team from among its own skaters, and
other teams were organized by clubs In
New York, Brooklyn, Montclair, Philadel
phia, Boston and Pittsburg. Several
of these banded themselves together
and founded the Amateur Hockey
league of America, which is destined to
become one of the most important of
national sporting bodies.
The Hockey league conducts a cham-
pionship tournament each winter, the
winner of which is open to challenge from
any representative team in the country
no$ associated with the league. The
championship games are contested with
all the yim, daring and determination
that mark the -big college football games.
The spectacular nature of the field and
its surroundings make the matches ideal
entertainment for the average American.
The game is played in two halves, each
lasting- 20 minutes, with an interval of
10 minutes between the halves. A referee
and two goal umpires are the only olli-
cials.
- .BUSY LITT! E PUCK.
The puck is faced by one player of j
either sale in the center of the field, be- |
tween two goals, when the game begins.
At the signal of the referee the puck is !
pushed either one way or the other and j
the scramble is on. All over the ice the
little puck slides with confusing rapidity,
with from four to twelve players fighting
for a crack at it. Sometimes, when the
player has a clear field, with good inter
ference, he will dribble the puck a dis
tance of fifty feet or more, one of the
prettiest feats of the game. To dribble
is to push the puck along by a steady
pressure of the flange of the hockey stick,
ocacsionally jerking it this side and that,
to avoid the stick of an opposing player.
Another effective play is to lift the
puck clear of the ice and send it spinning
through the air, often the entire length
of the rink. Tt requires a special knack
to do that successfully, and only a few
of the players can accomplish the trick
properly.
Agility and quickness are required of
all the players at all times. The con
test is one continuous series of quick
plays, which keep the boys on the jump
for the chances as well as for their bodily
protection. Rough play is not permitted,
but there are times when body checking
becomes more than a polite request to
ease up. In body checking one player
gives bis opponent the shoulder in order
to retard his progress. When the men
arc skating fast in opposite directions the
body check is apt to be more forceful than
good manners should justify.
GOALKEEPER'S PRIVILEGES.
Thc> goalkeeper is one of the most
important players of the team. It is his
function to guard the goal and keep the
puck from passing between the two flag
topped goal posts. He alone may use his
harids in stopping the puck, according to
Canadian rules. American rules do not
cover that point, and other phi y ers fre
quently avail themselves of the opportu
nity to block with their hands. The goal
keeper has other minor privileges, made
necessary by the demands of his position.
The trams entered in the race of the
Amateur Hockey league this year are
those of the Hockey club of New York,
New York Athletic club, Montclair
Athletic club, Brooklyn Skating club
and St. Nicholas Skating club. The
Hockey club, pioneers of the sport in the
United States, have developed another
; good t am. captained by Samuel M. Phil
lips, with E. J. O'Donnell as goalkeeper.
HAIR RISES ON END.
An eminent medical man, whose trea
tises on human hair have attracted much
notice, among many other striking
stew tia-nts as to woman's chief beauty,
remarked that "bristling" when used in
speaking of the human hair, is not a fig
ure. The hair is subject to and influ
enced by almost every passion of the hu
man mind, and emotional hair, of which
he lias treated especially, he claims is
quite commmi. Hair looks, feels and falls
differently when a person is in sorrow, joy
surprise or dejection. After a day or two
of deep mental study or violent bodily
exerciS'-. a most visible difference may be
detected by a practical observer. The
day is fated to come, he maintains, when
this coloring in the hair will be a valua
ble aid in identification.

Kngland gets $150,000 a year from the
worn-out uniforms of its army*

Women

women who undergo
a neTvous stTAin. are
compelled to regret
fully watch the grow
ing pallor of their
cheeks, the coming
wrinkles and thinness
that become more
''distressing every day.
Every woman
knows that ill-health
is a fatal enemy to
beauty and that good
health gives to the
plainest face an en

“That's what the fans yelled when my
son played his first game of big-league
ice hockey. I had expected that_"
But read what happened later!
by Lester Patrick
Coach of tho Now York Hoagan
LYNN PATRICK: THE
REDHEADED KID WHO
FOOLED HIS FATHER
AND BECAME A STAR
A s the play swirled swiftly up and down
the rink, I winced on the bench as
each tooth-rattling body check was
# % handed out. Toronto’s defense men
were hitting us with vigor — and they were
hulking fellows.
We had to win this game to keep in the
race for the 1937 Stanley Cup playoffs, and
things looked black. The Toronto Leafs al
ready had two goals and Buzz Boll, Syll Apps
and Harvey Jackson were skating like furies,
determined to protect that lead.
My Rangers' only chance of overhauling
the Leafs lay in our first line. Frank Boucher,
- the clever veteran, centered that first line of
ours, and on one wing he had Cecil Dillon,
who can really fly on steel. A redheaded young
ster playing his first season on the top line was
at left wing.
Suddenly Dillon saw his opening. A shim
mering ribbon of shaved ice squirted off his
blades as he suddenly shifted and swooped
across the mouth of the Toronto net. He
feinted Walter Broada out — and there was a
tell-tale bulge in the netting as Dillon’s shot
found its mark.
Again, a few minutes later, raven-haired
Dillon outskated his checker, deftly fondled a
pass on the end of his stick, and beat the
Toronto goaler. The pass? Oh, it had been
shuttled in by Boucher ... or maybe it was
that redheaded kid. The kid did seem to be in
on every play, at that . . . There was Dillon
& loose again! For the third time his shot lit that
tell-tale red bulb.
We won that game, 5 to 3, and I felt pretty
fine about it as I left the dressing room. In the
” passage I met King Clancy, veteran Toronto
defense man, and Conny Smythe, his boss.
Smythe asked:
“I suppose you think Cecil Dillon was the
best man on your club tonight?"
Well, I did, and I said so. After all, Dillon
had banged in three goals!
“That shows,” snorted Smythe, “how much
you know about it. You can have Dillon,
. Lester. I’ll take that kid of yours — for $10,
000. He was tops tonight. Didn’t you see who
set up the plays for those goals that Dillon
made?”
Yes, it had been my own flesh and blood —
24-year-old Lynn Patrick — skating out there
on the first line with Boucher and Dillon. And
as Smythe made his offer I felt a twinge of
guilt. I realized I had been leaning backward
too far, trying not to favor my son.
If I had needed any additional proof after
, Smythe waved that $10,000 offer in my face,
it came a few weeks later.
We were in a tight spot with Les Canadiens
of Montreal. The Flying Frenchmen were
leading the league when they came into Madi
son Square Garden that February night last
winter. Moreover, they had us down, two
goals to none, with eight minutes left to play.
Then it happened. Lynn streaked straight
down the middle, splitting the Canucks’ de
fense, took a pass from Joe Cooper at the goal
mouth and beat Hainsworth in the nets with a
pretty feint and shot.
After that the Canadiens watched him
every moment, hounding him, jostling him.
But somehow, Lynn tore loose again. He
stickhandled his way through brilliantly,
hurdling enemy sticks which were hooked out
in a desperate effort to halt his wild tour.
Finally he was in there again, eye-to-eye with
the goaltender. There were just sixty-three
seconds left to play when he shot that tying
goal. We won in overtime, 5 to 3. Lynn Patrick
had come a long way since his debut in pro
fessional hockey.
Lynn had been pretty terrible when he first
donned a Ranger suit back in the 1934-1935
season.
1 can hear it now, as it rolled down from
the top balcony of Madison Square Garden —
that insistent demand, chanted over and over.
"Take him out! We want Somers?”
That cry stabbed me — hard. My team,
with some of its old stars fading fast, seemed
to be floundering. The fans were impatient,
angry. Wise in the ways of hockey, they kept
up that chant: “We want Somers!”
Now Artie Somers, squatting there on the
Ranger bench beside me, could have done a
much better job playing center on our third
line than that redheaded youngster of mine.
I knew he was no star, believe me. And
newspapermen whose colorful stories had
called me a hockey wizard, “the Gray Fox of
the Rinks,” felt that I knew it.
But I had made up my mind I was going to
see the redheaded kid through. Lynn, you see,
had always had visions of being a big star, but
I had always told him that he never had a
chance in hockey, that he wasn’t made for the
game.
Lynn was bom and brought up in Victoria,
capital city of British Columbia, where the
weather is so mild that often the entire winter
passes without a single day of outdoor skating.
While lads in other parts of the Dominion
practically teethed on their hockey sticks,
Lynn played other games. He did have some
hockey at the indoor rink in Victoria — but
in 1929 the rink burned down. Lynn was 17
then — and heartbroken.
When I inaugurated my hockey school in
October, 1934, Lynn begged me for a chance
to attend. I let him come, but told him out
right that he didn’t have a chance. Then
Boucher and Cook batted in. They tokl me
in front of Lynn that they thought I was
wrong — that he had possibilities!
The boy was overjoyed. I, of course, was
furious. However, as a result of this interfer
ence by Boucher and Cook, Lynn jumped onto
the Rangers, without any professional ex
perience — an unheard-of thing.
Almost untO it dawned on me that he was a
’’find” for the Rangers I was hoping Lynn
would turn to something surer, safer and saner
for a living. Having taken many a thumping
and gone down where my nose, ears and eyes
were hobnobbing with some defense man’s
razor-sharp blades, I knew well that hockey
is never safe, and not always sane.
The 1935-36 season was the first year in
Ranger history that we missed the Stanley
Cup playoffs, but Lynn’s rise to stardom was
some balm for the break-up of hockey’s great
est forward line — Bill and Bunny Cook and
. Frank Boucher.
Last year I profited handsomely by the
brilliant play of my son. He shot .many vital
goals in the amazing march of a team that was
a 50 to 1 shot to get into the Stanley Cup
finals, after finishing last the year before.
As far as Lynn’s case goes — and I insist
that any big-city lad has as much chance as
he had to make the Rangers, as far as oppor
tunities and experience are concerned — won
ders never cease. His brilliant work did not
end with the regular season; under the stress
and strain of Stanley Cup play he continued
to climb to real stardom.
In our first game in the playoffs, against
Toronto, the Leafs were favored to snuff us
right out of the running. The play was fast,
hard and scoreless for 55 minutes. Then Lynn
crashed through to notch our first goal — the
opening wedge for a victory that was to bring
us also into a conquest of the highly-favored
Montreal Maroons and smackbang into the
defending champions, the mighty Red Wings
of Detroit.
You can imagine how I felt as Lynn pounded
in two goals in our first tiff with the Red
Wings, to lead the way in an upset 5 to 1 vic
tory over the champions. That, for me, was
the climax of a very happy year, even though
the Rangers didn’t have quite enough left to
carry on and capture the prized Stanley Cup.
Hockey has held many thrills for me. I have
been in fourteen Stanley Cup finals — the
hockey equivalent of baseball’s World Series
— in my thirty-four years of major-league
hockey. I’ve seen Broadway take to hockey
and acclaim my stars.
But nothing has given me the flush of satis
faction that came with the realization that
my bungling but persistent redheaded boy
had made the grade to stardom.

WASHINGTON, D. C., SATURDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1936. PAGE B-^l~
WORLD’S WOMAN HOCKEY STARS PERFORM HERE TODAY
BRITISH TEAM MEETING WASHINGTON
Contest at Cathedral School Is Preliminary to Third Triennial Conference of the Present
International Federation to Be Held in Philadelphia—Additional Member \ _
Clubs Are Expected From Foreign Nations.
_r——■
(1) Into the clear and executing a push shot toward goal.
(2) The Washington Field hockey team which will meet the
all-English field hockey team here this afternoon in a game
greliminary to the international matches in Philadelphia,
eginning October 20. They are—left to right: Norum
Spaulding, athletic director. Mount Vernon Seminary: Clara
May Tarbette, Ethel Shammer, Luce Sanborne, Elizabeth
Cooper, Hazel Sayre, team captain and physical education direc
tor, Madeira School; Betty Craig of American University. Mary
Spraule. director of athletics, Sidwell-Friends’ School; Elizabeth
Plimpton of Alice Deal Junior High School. Betty Gilbert and
Jenny Turbull of George Washington University. (3) About
to strike the ball. (4) Reach of players who still have two
hands on their sticks. _—Star Staff Photos.
1 “ 4
By Vesta Cummings.
ANGUARD of fleet-footed young
women who will doubtless In
vade arenas of American sport
in increasing numbers as a new
•r» of international competition in
women's athletics dawns, the all-Eng
lish field hockey team, acknowledged
to be the finest women hockey players
In the world, are meeting the Washing
ton field hockey team at 3 o'clock
this afternoon at the National Cathe
dral School hockey field.
The game is an event preliminary to
the third triennial conference of the
International Federation of Women ?
Hockey Associations, which will meet
from October 20 to November 1 in
Philadelphia, bringing women hockey
players from South Africa, Denmark.
Australia, Ireland, Wales and Scotland.
Every possible accent of the English
tongue is being heard on American
hockey fields these days, as expert
women players wax their hockey sticks
for games scheduled from coast to
poast. the final contest to take place
an November 19 In California. Den
mark, so far, Is the only non-English
ypeaking country in the conference.
In light of the growing Interest in
aompetitive sports for women, spurred
by their dramatic successes at the
Olympic games this Summer, the
match today is attracting the atten
tion of both men and women in the
amateur sport world. Although no
women's hockey teams competed for
World supremacy at the 1936 Olympic
games, it is thought that this ancient
■port—a game that has been played for
more than 2,500 years and Is the na
tional game of India—will be repre
tented by the feminine sex at the 1940
•vent.
The Englisn gins may sureiy win
today, according to Hazel Sayre, cap
tain of the District team, but the
Washington outfit Is displaying pride
and excitement about defending its
goal against the champion Cardinal
eleven. The honor of defeating a crack
English women's hockey team still re
mains open to ladies all over the globe,
according to Miss Sayre. It has never
keen done.
In some instances friendships made
at the two previous conferences of the
association, and when the English field
hockey team invaded America in 1928.
are being renewed. Members of the
team from England are house guests
of hockey enthusiasts and girls' schools
to Washington, Baltimore, and Phila
delphia, and were received by Lads
Lindsay at the British Embassy yes
terday. They were guests of Mount
Vernon Seminary for tea Thursday
and will lunch with the Washingtoi
Field Hockey Association at a suburbar
Inn tomorrow. Today, after the game
the ladies will talk It over at tea serve*
at the National Cathedral School. Thi
National Capital is particularly privi
leged in being scheduled to entertah
til of the foreign hockey players whei
they come down from Philadelphi:
Wednesday. October 28, to be escortei
on a tour of the city by the local asso
elation. It is thought that severs
embassies and legations will receiv
them tt this time.
'T'HIS is the first year that the in
• ternational conference of womei
hockey players has met In Amerlct
although English teams have com
peted here several times before. Mem
bera ot both the English and Amer
lean teams are composed primarily o
coaches and physical training direc
tort at girls' schools and colleges, a
well as superior athletes among re
cent graduates and undergraduate!
according to Miss Jean A. Pearsor
, treasurer of the District Hockey Asso
elation and physical education direc
tor at Mount Vernon Seminary. Othe
rfiw of tha Washington organla
»
a
——---v
tion are Elizabeth Plimpton, presi
dent, of Alice Deal Junior High School ►
Miriam L. Spaulding, vice president, of
Mount Vernon Seminary: and Mrs.
E. P. James, secretary, of the Uni
versity of Maryland.
No members of the Washington
field hockey team will be on the
picked eleven to represent America
during the tournament at Philadel
phia. although the team is made up
of outstanding players in local
matches. This afternoon's line-up is
as follows:
Left wing, Betty Craig, student at
American University: left inner,
Ethel Shamberger, student at the
University of Maryland; center for
ward, Luce Sanborne, teachers of
English at Madeira School: right in
ner, Elizabeth Climpton, physical ed
ucation teacher at Alice Deal Junior
High School; right wing, Mary
Spraule, physical director at Sidwell
Friends’ School; left halfback, Ethel
1 —-V
Shamer, Sweet Briar alumna; center
halfback. Jenny Turnbull of the
George Washington University physi
cal education department; right half
back, Doris Hannon, student at Hood
College; left fullback, Elizabeth
Cooper, teacher at the Alice Deal
Junior High School; captain. Hazel
Sayre, physical education director at
Madeira School; and goal keeper,
Betty Sands, physical education in
structor at Marjorie Webster School.
Among the reserves are Miriam L.
Spauling. Mount Vernon Seminary;
Betty Gilbert, Mount Vernon alumna;
Margaret Bennett of Marjorie Web
ster School; and Cora May Tarbette.
Jenny Turnbull was a member of
the all-American touring team rep
resenting America on lacrosse last
Summer in Berlin. Jean Pearson is
umpiring for the Capital hockey play
ers today.
TJOCKEY playing enthusiasts among
1 women, with local teams formed
all over the globe, first met interna
tionally in London in 1924, with Amer
ica represented, to discuss interna
tional competition. Attendance was
excellent at this meeting of many na
tions, and it was unanimously voted
to form an association.
On account of the great distances
between interested countries—Scot
land and Australia for an example—
it was three years before the actual
meeting took place, in January, 1927,
when a constitution was accepted and ;
the federation became a fact, dedi
cated "to further the best interests
of the game among women of all na
tions. to promote friendly intercourse
among players, to work for uniformity
of rules, and to promote international
matches."
The first conference was held In
Geneva in 1930, and though no tour
nament took place at this time, sev
eral exhibition games were played.
In 1933 the conference was held In
Denmark, with all of the present mem
bership teams competing except South
Africa and Australia, as well as visit
ing teams from Germany and Hoi- j
land, and an "overseas, etc.” team
made up of visiting players not con
nected with any national team.
South Africa has become a mem
ber since the last conference, and
is therefore displaying its tournament
skill for the first time in an alierr.
land, while, although Australian worn- I
en hockey players have been members
since the federation was bom. they j
have never before attended an inter- j
national conference.
Heading the English field hockey
team on its first visit here in eight ;
years is Miss Mildred K. Knott, right
fullback, who played not only against I
the touring Americans in 1933. but
against some of their predecessors on
American fields. Miss Audrey F. Cat
tell is another member of the Cardinal
Red eleven to return, after having;
played here in 1928.
'J'WO of the English players, Miss.j
Jane Dickinson, vice captain andjj
right inner, and Miss Isobel Denton,
halfback, have been at the hockey
camp at Mount Pocono, Pa., since the
end of August. They are in the line
up for today's game in Washington.
Miss Dickinson is one of five members
3f the 1936 all-England first eleven.
Miss Knott. Marjorie E. Collins, left
fullback; Kathleen Harrison, goal
seeper. and Edith M. Higgins, right
wing, are the others. The remaining
members of the squad, all high-rank
ing players, but not national eleven
choices of this year, are Phyllis Carle
bach. right half; Christian Goodman,
center forward; Joan Law. wing;
Margaret J. Lodge, left or center half .
Margaret Mackintosh, left inner, and
Rosemary Marriott. Phyllis Bryant,
a noted umpire, is here as manager.
With the team, and even better
known in America than many of its
members, are England's six delegates
to the conference. Miss H H. Light,
president of the All-England Women's
Hockey Association; Miss W A Bau
mann, secretary, and Miss H.
Bothamley, treasurer.
Field hockey 1* unique. Its devotees
say. in that it is a game played not
only in nearly every country of the
world, but by both men and women.
Unofficial international matches have
been arranged between neighboring
countries for years. As far as the
United States is concerned, the first
official games took place In 1921, when
a team from England came over and
gave a skillful demonstration of indi
vidual technique and co-ordinated
team play. At that time the visitors
not only exhibited, but coached, and
were largely responsible for giving
American hockey new impetus.
In 1924 the first American team
went overseas and played a series of
matches in the British Isles. Against
the best English hockey the American
players of that time were helpless, but
they gained experience. Between 1924
and 1933 touring teams from England.
Ireland and Scotland came to the
United States to play against local
associations. In the meantime the
international federation had been
formed, and in 1933 held its first
tournament in conjunction with its
triennial conference in Copenhagen,
w here it was voted to meet this year
in America.
IN THE meantime interest in inter
sectional competition has been
spreading rapidly in the United
States, according to Miss Pearson.
Having originated first along the At
lantic Seaboard local organizations
are now moving South, Virginia hav
ing joined the Southeast section of
the organization this year.
Spectators at the National Cathdral
School hockey field this afternoon,
and those at the matches to be held
at the Philadelphia Cricket Club,
Chestnut Hills. Philadelphia, later in
the month, will be watching the most
educated hockey sticks in women's
hands today. Twenty-four interna
tional matches will be played in 12
days.
The visitors will compete all the
way from Los Angeles to Boston in
both pre-conference and post-confer
ence games before returning home,
the game today being one of the
earliest on the schedule.
Twenty-six members of the English
and Welsh women's field hockey teams
arrived in New York last Monday on
the Queen Mary, the English girls
leaving at once for Baltimore, where
they played Wednesday. From Wash
ington they will go to Richmond and
Sweet Briar College in Virginia, to
play Wednesday and Friday of next
week. On October 19 they will meet
the United States touring team In
Morristown, N. J., and on November 3
(Continued on Page 3-2.)

ALL WASHINGTON STUDENTS TO BE MADE SPORT CONSCIOUS.
_ .. _ . . _.
Schools to Adopt Slogan, "A Team for Every
Boy or Girl, and Every Boy or Girl on
a Team,” in City Athletic Program.
r
Great Requisites Are Upheld by Supervisor!
Bayh, in Charge of New System of Health
and Physical Education for the District. \
By John Jay Daly.
(C A TEAM for every boy and |
/\ girl, and every boy and girl
\ on a team.” That is the
■* goal of Birch E. Bayh. who
recently came here from Terre Haute,
InJ... to supervise a new system of
health and physical education in the
Washington schools, and who has in
teresting plans for a citywide athletic
program.
He has definite ideas about adolescent
girls and boys and what they need
in the way of school sport and ath
letics.
“It is a large order,” says Mr. Bayh
(who incidentally pronounces his
name as though it were spelled "by,”
and who comes by his love for athletics
naturally—through a long line of
gymnasts.) "It may take several
years to complete; but—it can be done
with the co-operation of all con
cerned.”
All concerned in this work make
up a big army—the boys and girls
themselves, their parents or guardians,
the alumni and alumnae of the high
schools, and old Johnnie Q. Public.
While the public has a lot to do
with any program in the public
schools, since the public pays the
taxes—and pays, and pays and pays—
l the first persons to please in Mr.
! Bayh’s estimate are the boys and girls
■ involved.
i After all, they are the primary
\ cause for striving after an effect. If
i what follows does not quite satisfy
I them, and if they do not enter into
■ it with their whole hearts and souls,
1 the plan will fail.
> To get an idea of what Mr. Bayh is
driving at, you'll have to discount a
lot of old, outworn theories as they
■ pertain to school athletics, hereafter
! to be known as physical education.
In the old days, as almost every
body knows, only the high schools
. ariS colleges really figured in ath
. letics-*and, then, only a few high
[ school boys played on the so-called
varsity teams.
s Nor were they always boys. Some
. times the athletes were old enough to
have graduated from college or uni
’ versKy.
. TJNDER the new system—when
r working well—all that will be
- changed.
1
To begin with, there will be new
age limit* for the varsity players—on
senior or high school teams. This will
be brought about gradually. Up to
the present time a boy might play on
a team until he Is ready to step into
man’s estate—at 21 years of age. In
a couple of years that age limit will
be knocked down to 19. If there are
any huskies who fail to graduate and
thus remain in high school indefinite
ly they will not be permitted to pit
their weight, strength and experience
against adolescent boys.
On the basis of a sound mind in a
sound body, health and physical edu
cation in the Washington schools will
hereafter be a sort of prescribed
course advocated for all youngsters
with good, stout hearts and sound
lungs. So that the few at the topi, or
the peak of physical perfection, will
not get all the benefits as well as the
glory of competitive games, all boys
and girls able to run or walk may
take an active part in the new ath
letics.
This is going to fake time, for there
is more to this plan than meets the
eye. It involves a lot of thought and
deliberation, study and planning.
Three great requisites are named
by Mr. Bayh:
First, facilities—such as base ball
and foot ball fields, tennis courts,
cinder tracks, hand ball alleys and
all that sort of thing.
Second, supplies and equipment
such as balls, nets, tennis rackets,
bats and other paraphernalia.
Third, leadership—both adult and
pupil.
TT MIGHT seem a strange situ
ation, but Washington at the mo
ment-even if it is the Nation's Capi
tal—has not the proper facilities for
a comprehensive health and physical
education system in the public schools;
nor in the private schols, except in
rare instances.
, Take the high schools, one by one:
Eastern High is the outstanding
school in the city, judged by athletic
facilities. There are some 3.000 pupils
over there, but there are also several
acres of good playing field—for foot
ball, base ball, track and other sports.
Central High, with approximately
2,800 pupils, is crowded for athletic
space.
Western High is in fairly good shape
with 1.500 pupils and a good-sized i
stadium several blocks from the main
plant.
McKinley, with 2,400 pupils, has a
good ' field—but the school could do
with more space—and the Roosevelt
High School—with 2,000 boys and
girls—is not so cramped for playing
quarters, while Woodrow Wilson High,
with only a thousand pupils, has yet
to test its faculties. The field is under
going certain revisions, due to some

That’s hockey, toughest of sports
Cuts, slashes and broken bones
are just part of the night’s work
* to the men on the ice
Arthur Mann
Professional ice hockey is no tea party
for several reasons, but chiefly because
you can take your lumps or leave them
at a tea party; whereas in a hockey
game you must take the lumps as they come,
which is pretty often.
It is true that many of the game’s injuries
can be avoided through care and caution, but
the player who tries it soon finds himself
employed only at the job of seeking em
ployment.
Thus, the young man who decides to earn
a livelihood by nudging a rubber lozenge
around on the ice enters the toughest sport
yet devised for the benefit of cash customers.
He knows he cannot escape at least one smart
ing injury in each three years of competition;
that the immutable law of averages says he
must be rendered unconscious, slashed badly
or bruised internally.
ino hockey player wants to get
hurt, and yet every one of them
expects to get hurt. If he isn’t
injured one night, nor the next,
nor the next, his apprehension
mounts, because he knows that
when the crash does arrive, it’ll
be a honey. .
Why do they do it? Nobody
knows, themselves least of all.
somewhere among the following reasons is
the answer:
1. It’s a good living.
2. It’s exciting.
3. Fame and glamor await the stars.
Most surprising about this roughest of
games is the fact that tragedies rarely occur.
But near-tragedies —
One was curtained from the crowd in the
early twenties when Newsy Lalonde, long a
factor in big-league hockey, was a pillar of
playing strength on the Montreal Canadiens.
Playing in his home city, Newsy plunged into
a mass of swirling bodies, flying skates and
slashing sticks. The puck was free. He could
sweep-check, grab it and start for —
He felt a strange throbbing deep in the
calf of his leg. It was too deep and too strange
to be something ordinary. He stopped, looked
down and observed that he was skating on red
ice. Players halted the scramble and picked
him up, but that wasn’t enough, as Frank
Patrick, then the referee, could see.
Frank plunged two fingers deep into the
leg wound, and plugged up a deep slash which
had severed an artery. They carried Newsy
from the rink and to the hospital with Frank
Patrick’s fingers still in that leg wound. They
were removed only when Newsy was placed
upon the operating table. Had they come out
sooner, Lalonde would have bled to death.
That slashed leg was an accident, but many
injuries are not accidents.
Rabbit McVeigh, who starred with the
New York Americans, was the victim in such a
case while playing for Regina, Saskatchewan.
Some one wrapped an ash hockey stick
around Rabbit’s curly blond head and ren
dered him senseless all over. Rusty Crawford,
a teammate, appointed himself a committee
of one to square the account.
Not many minutes later, as Rabbit lay on
the dressing room table, Crawford came in,
banned from the game with a major penalty.
“Boy, did I get him!” Rusty muttered.
“Did you get that guy!" his mates echoed
at the end of the period. “You took the ear
right off the side of his head!”
Ernie "Moose” Johnson, toughest of all
hockey players, was skating in a western
Canada mix-up when somebody gave him the
full force of a stick against his jaw. The
referee sent the offender to the penalty box.
Then, to the surprise of all beholders, Moose
Drowtfnf by
Col* Bradley
* '»*• »pr.«r<4 ...
HOT MOMENTS AT THE NET: A DRIVE FOR GOAL THAT FAILED
stood in the center of the rink, shaking his
head and gesticulating wildly. He began to
skate in circles. Players rushed to him.
Lo and behold, his tongue was jammed up
against his top teeth, solidly impaled. They
held his head and pulled the tongue loose
from his top incisors. It was a ghastly bite.
They started to escort Moose to the side
lines, but he fought free.
Before they could stop him, Moose skated
over to the penalty box and whipped his
stick in a beautiful arc. It connected with the
noggin of his assailant and broke both — the
stick and the assailant’s noggin.
Nobody ever knew how Moose Johnson
got so tough, but tough he was. He had taken
up hockey after losing three fingers of his
right hand in a railroad accident — he had
been a train brakeman. At the age of forty
four Moose went back to railroading. The ice
game had been a pleasantly rough interlude
in a colorful life.
Probably the second toughest player in
professional hockey was Helge Bostrum. He
was with the Chicago Black Hawks when he
made his celebrated demonstration against
complete incapacitation.
Bill Cook, wing of the New York Rangers,
came down and attacked with the puck.
Bostrum, playing defense, sprawled with the
elusive Cook after a heavy body check. Cook
got up, but Helge didn't.
Players picked him up, and his foot dangled
loosely. They carried Helge to the hospital,
and said goodby to him, because the doctors
said that the skate slash across the instep
would take about 100 stitches — practically
a career in sewing.
Helge refused to say goodby to hockey. He
rested a year and returned to the game.
Ching Johnson, of the New York Rangers,
has earned the name of “zipper man” because
5,000 stitches have been put in at one time
or another to hold his massive framework
together.
Mid-way in the 1931-32 season Ching made
one of his most unfortunate attempts to barge
through a couple of human beings. Usually
they gave ground — or ice — but this time
they met Ching’s charge and spilled with him.
A few minutes later when he took one of his
infrequent rests during a game, he complained
to Manager Lester Patrick as follows:
“Something’s wrong with my jaw!”
He was more than right. The jaw was
broken in three places.
“He won’t play again this season,” the
doctors confided to Patrick.
They wired his jaw three ways, put him
in a neck harness. And he was back again
late in the season.
Three years ago he broke his leg. Again
the doctors pronounced him through, prob
ably for all time. But Ching was bad: before
long. He has broken a wrist and collar bone,
too — almost everything except his spirit.
But he continues to play hockey, and, in so
doing, he brings business to Madison Square
Garden and to Polyclinic Hospital across the
street. He is their best customer, and times
will be dull around there when Ching stops
coming over to be patched up or hemstitched.
But down deep, even these so-called tough
hockey players have their weak momentsv
Lionel Conacher had one in the dressing quar
ters of the Garden. A stick had slashed across
his already-battered nose, cutting his eye-lid.
Conacher sat on the rubbing table, clench
ing the edge with white-knuckled fists. His
eyes were closed and he refused to open them
for the doctor. They swabbed the blood away
to see what damage had been done, but they
couldn’t be sure as to how far beyond the
lid the damage went. It was a hole and the
eyeball could have been slashed.
Anxious seconds passed before the great
player would risk the shock of opening an eye
from which he might not see again. Finally
the hands unclenched. The tension left his
heavyweight frame and he opened his eyes.
He could see. The wound was stitched and
patched and he went out to finish the game.
But, you see, these big tough players have
their weak moments!

Just when the-Indian is about to
pass out of sport limelight up pops
Jim Cree, of the tribe of Iroquois, to
command attention.
Cree will not bid for honors on the
diamond or gridiron where other red
skins have starred, but in ice hockey,
that dazzling, slambang winter sport
He has won a place on the Cleveland
hockey team, which will play the best
in the United States and Canada.
Chief Bender and Chief Meyers up
held the honor of the redskin in base
hall a long time, but the Fed league
tied a can to Bender last season and
the New York Giant management be
gan greasing the way for the exit of
Meyers.
That leaves only Jim Thorpe, Chief
Johnson and Bluejacket, just aver
age players, as therepresentatives of
the Indian in baseball. LeRoy and
Jude passed out some time ago.
The Carlisle, football team was wal
loped right an4 left this year. In fact,
Carlisle had not turned out a dazzler
since the day of Thorpe on the grid
jron and athletic field. Tom Long
boat, the marathon runner, has been
through some time.
Cree, the new redskin in sport,
looks like a live one. At first he
was slated for a place as substitute
on the hockey team, then for a de
fense position. Suddenly he began
to show the craft for which the In
dian is noted and now he has been
given the rover jobthe hardest and
most spectacular on a hockey team.
The rover, as the name indicates,
is the fellow who has to go out and
battle the opposition for possession
of the puck. He has -to-be speedy,
tricky and cooL Cree Js all of that.
It is predicted he will be as good as
Gustine and Paddy Sullivan, two of
the best rovers-United States hockey
ever produced.
Max Carey, Pittsburgh Pirate, led
the National league in base stealing
this year with the lowest mark in the
history of the organization, just as
Larry Doyle led the batters with the
lowest stick average that ever topped
the heap. Carey swiped 32 bags.
George Burns led In 1914 with 62,
Carey in 1913 with 61, Bescher in
1912 with 67, and also in 1911 with
80, the league record.
WHY OUR ARMS SWING
This may not sound like a very
important question, but I would like
to know why people swing their arms
when they walk. I believe everybody
does it, so it cannot be a peculiarity
with certain people. Jas. Howard.
It's old Mother Nature herself who
sets our arms a-swinging when we
walk. And she has the best of" rea
sons for doing so, for it's the swing of
the arms backward and forward that
helps us, unconsciously, to keep our
balance as we walk.
Try to walk with your arms held
stiffly at your side and you'll find
that your progress forward first on.
one foot, then on the other, is much
more difficult and your carriage is
less? graceful than if your arms were
swinging free.

The Sunday Star Pictorial Magazine, Washington, D. C., January 23, 1949 Page 5
A Goalie Dresses for the Role
'T'HE MO8T-DRES8ED, if
not the best-dressed, man
in sports is the goal-tender
on a hockey team.
Paul Gauthier, one of the
two goalies on the Washing
ton Lions (Lou Crowdis is the
°*her), says his working
costume weighs gJ pounds,
and most of It is podding.
Such a high degree of pro
tection becomes understand
able when you watch him at
his Job, which calls for him
to stand at a m—h cage and
wait for burly, oncoming op
ponents to flick a rock-hard
rubber disc at him.
His gear includes T*ratrs. leg
pods, chest protector, arm
pads, padded pants, gloves,
stockings, jersey and under
wear. The only thing left un
protected is his face, but the
thought that he might get hit
there with the fast-flying—
and sometimes high-flying—
puck doesn’t occur to him
during a hot fracas around
the net because, as he says,
“things are happening too
fast.”
He has been badly hurt
once. When he was playing
for Houston one night in
Omaha, an opposing player
crashed him back into the
net, and he hit his head on
the iron stanchion. He got a
concussion of the brain and
was out of action for six
weeks. He has had scores of
bruises and strained and even
torn muscles, but he hardly
considers them injuries.
The trick in being a goalie,
he explains, is to feint the
oncoming player into making
the first move.
“If you make the first move
you’re beaten,” he asserts.
“The guy with the puck will
see what you're going to do
and shoot it right past you.
The thing to do is to make
the man with the puck com
mit himself first.
“For Instance, if two of
fensive players are rushing at
you and one has the puck,
you might deliberately block
the net <?n his side, and the
split second you see him [>m«
the puck to the other guy you
dive for the other side of the
net because you know it’ll be
coming in—just that quick.”
Why did he become a goal
tender, Instead of one of the
fast-moving and more spec
tacular forwards?
“I was too small for the
forward line,” he explains.
“I weighed only 127 when I
was 18—don’t weigh much
more right now—and I tried
out for forward, but I got
bounced around too much. I
liked the game too well to
quit, so I dropped back to
goal.”
Gauthier, 33, has been play
ing hockey since he was 5
years old. Like the great ma
jority of professional ice
hockey players, he was born
and reared in Canada. Win
nipeg was his city and he
took to hockey like the boys
of this country take to base-'
ball.
“Kids up there skate from
the time they're 2 years old,”
he says. “Wherever they find
an empty lot they call the

fire department to pour on
the water and they’ve got a
hockey rink.”
By the time he was 18
Gauthier was playing on a
Dominion champion amateur
team and going to the Uni
versity of Manitoba. He stud
ied pharmacy for a year and
then transferred to the Uni
versity of Montreal. When
he got an offer to go with
the Montreal Canadiens (sic),
he quit school to become a
professional hockey player.
He was lust as thrilled at the
idea of playing with the
Canadiens as a young base
ball player in this country
would be to get an offer from
the Cleveland Indians or the
New York Yankees.
Gauthier first served with
the Lions from 1941 to 1943.
Then he put in some -time
with Cleveland and Buffalo
and served a year in the
Army as a pharmacist’s as
sistant in a hospital.
IBs home is Hamden, Conn.,
a suburb of New Haven. In
the off-season he has a de
livery route for a soft-drink
firm. He has a daughter and
a son, 10, who is already play
ing hockey in competition.
Does Gauthier want him to
become a pro?
“I won’t encourage him,”
says Gauthier. “For myself; I
love it, but I’d rather see him
in baseball. It’s not so rough,
and he’ll have a longer
career.” —8. b.

BY FRANK CARLYN.
■W -WT JT HAT 18 the fastest sport? What
m M f Is the flashiest yet most gruel
m/M/ ing physical contest of today?
yP' Which takes the swiftest
muscles, the quickest brain, the
greatest stamina, the hardest body, the strong
est heart?
Root ball enthusiasts may point to the daz
eling rough-and-tumble scrimmages which are
the essence of the game, to the black eyes and
broken noses, pulled ligaments and battered
torsos which also seem part of the game, and
to the physical exhaustion resulting from the
fierce play which often necessitates carrying
Worn out combatants from the gridiron. Since
the introduction of new rules, especially those
regarding aerial attacks, in the last few years,
foot ball has certainly been given winged feet.
The introduction of a bit of basket ball into
the national Fail pastime tends to lend credence
to the claims of court enthusiasts that theirs
Is the fastest sport, to basket ball every muscle
of the body is continually at work at top speed,
twisting, running and throwing.
gOXINO is a sport which might have a
better claim than the two foregoing. It
combines the speed of basket ball with the
body-bruising elements of foot ball. Proponents
of the ring sport will remind you of the sledge
hammer Wows the fighter's body must stand.
Os the steel-springed lega which must move
lightly as a dancer's yet always be solidly
placed to give or take a blow, of the clever
brain which, punch-drunk though It may be.
must order ttred muscles and bruised fists to
jab. swing, guard and dodge.
Any list of speedy sports would be incom
plete without those of the cinder track. What
sport can be faster than the'dashes with flying
legs and pumping arms propelling the body a
hundred yards in less than 10 seconds* Then
there are (he hurdles, requiring minute mus
cular control with swift limbs, a keen eye and a
brain accurately judging distance and height
all in the course of split seconds. So on up
the range of races to the marathon with its
24-odd miles of grueling, heartbreaking and un
faltering effort.
Every sport will have its defenders, more or
less prejudiced as most fans are when their
favorite pastime is at Issue, who will advance
reasons why it should be considered the swiftest
of athletic contests. Judging by the number
of fans who pay homage to It. base ball will
have the most defenders. The national pastime
Is certainly a speedy game and the crack of
bat on ball is often the signal for maneuvers
eo swift as to challenge the eye to follow them.
There is one sport Just as old but not quite
■a widespread in this country as any of the
above which has gradually been usurping the
claim of being the fastest sport Ice hockey,
until a few years ago, was a sport confined to
the Northern regions, where ice formed regu
larly enough to permit a season's play. With
the introduction of artificial indoor rinks, how
ever, It has gradually spread and Is taking Its
ptaoe throughout America as a contender with

and considers it the fiercest as well as the
swiftest of all sports. He is shown here

late foot ball and basket ball tor Winter popu
larity. No small measure of its rapid growth
as a major Winter sport oaa be attributed to
Its constant data that It Is the taataat of
•ports.
Perhaps the earliest form of hockey generally
known in the United States was the game of
“shinny.- played on the corner lot with a tin
can or done and with sticks having a thick
knob or curve on the end. What few rates
there were to this crude sport differed .widely in
various sections. One. however, was widely
known and extremely popular with the players
of the sport. It dealt with the penalty for
offside play. This penalty was a crack on the
shins with the opponent's dub. accompanied by
the admonition, “Shinny on your own side."
This game was probably a derivation of a
cruder form of hockey played in Scotland,
loiown as “shinty." A similar game played in
Ireland was called “hurley." Derivation of
the present name "hockey" is commonly at
tributed to the French “hoquet," a shepherd’s
crook referring to the shape of the stick used
In the early stages of the ’game Various modi
fications of the sport were played in Northern
Europe and Asia. The ancient Romans played
What might be termed a form of hockey, using
a bent stick on hard ground or ioe.
England first took steps to 187 S to make the
game more concrete and less haphazard. A
group of fans composed the Men’s Hockey As
sociation, made a few vital rules and dubbed
the resulting game “field hockey." The game

may see the game played not only In the universities, colleges and high schoefek
but also in the grammar schools throughout the Nation.
What the fan’s opinion of how fast or harsh a sport may be often
varies widely with that of the player. The average foot ball coach will
pooh-pooh the charge that present-day foot ball is too rough, claiming
that a well trained and hardened player has slight chance for serious
of field hocked as known In hundreds of girls’
schools and colleges to a descendant of this
Men's Hockey Association contest, with the
rougher features removed. The Wtmbl don
Club rules, drawn up In IMS. governing the
game, which was then played with a hard
rubber ball and bent sticks, are still effective
aa far as essential points of play are concerned.
The sport gained immense popularity in Eng
land. Ireland, Scotland and Wales, and count
less international matches were played By
1907 London alone had 81 teams.
Two years before the Wimbledon dub to
England had drawn up a set of rules gov
erning the game in that section, the first game
played on ice to America took place. The
Victoria Hockey Club and the McGill Univer
sity Hockey dub met to Montreal in 1881, and
the sport, destined to become one of major
rank, had its inception in America After this
clash a code of rules was devised through the
efforts of the Victoria Club, and the game rap
idly spread, and to 1884 a general tournament
was held, to 1887 the greatest step toward
consolidation and clarification of the rules
governing the sport was made with the organ
ization of the Amateur Hockey Association in
Canada. Since that time the game's growth
has been steady. It has crossed the Canadian
border, invaded New England and Midwestern
States near the boundary line. Perfecting of
indoor rink equipment further aided Its prog
ress. If experiments with a new type of arti
ficial Ice prove successful, hockey enthusiasts
Injuries. Therefore, it would seem logical to get the opinion of some
outstanding player of ioe hockey to see if the players themselves look
upon the fascinating sport as a fast, fierce game.
J-JIB MILKS, versatile and flashy captain of the Quakers, thinks
loe hockey is not only the speediest sport, but is. in addition,
the most furiously fought and fiercest of all athletic combats.
Hibbert Harry Milks has been playing big-time hockey for
11 seasons. As a boy he played with the Canadian grammar
school teams and at 17 had fought his way to the top of the
youthful ranks. He was given his first big start with the
Ontario Gunners* Club to 1919. After rounding out his
experience with three seasons with that aggregation, he
invaded the States. He played on the Pittsburgh Ama
teur Club In 1922 and then returned to Ottawa, where
he joined the ranks of the New Edinburgh Canoe Club
during 1923-24. Back to Pittsburgh again with the
Yellow Jackets. Milks continued hte climb to the top.
His popularity to PittdHirgh is being duplicated in
Philadelphia as pilot of the Quakers.
“Ice hockey is the fastest sport,'’ said Milks;
"there is no doubt about it that I can see. Any
one who has played the game knows what
I mean when I say its speed Is a continuous
•train. Often a player will be skating at top
spaed for five minutes at a stretch. Then
•gain, to the course of a game the player may
travel the course of the rink from 100 to 200
times, stopping, starting, turning and twisting.
When you consider how fast even an ordinary
skater can travel on the let, you realise the
speed with which all this to being accom
plished. You either have to keep up this
nerve-racking pane or relinquish your post to
a substitute.
"I think it to a faster, harder game than
modern foot ball, to the first place, ft calls
for a quicker brain in analyzing formations
and plays. In foot ball there are a certain
numbv of formations by means of which tho
offensive to carried on. The team is drilled
in these formations until each member knows
just what he is to do In each play. The re
sult is that each offensive rush Is Just one well
timed machlne-like move after another. These
plays never vary.
“But to ice hockey there Is no time tor
set formations, no time for signals for this or
that offensive. When the player finds himself
with the puck at the end of his stick and op
ponent* streaking toward him. be has no time
to call his men back In a huddle and devise
a winning formation. In a split fraction of
a second he must figure out his own offensive
and execute even as he plans it. Speedy skat
ing and fast stickwork ate essentials of the
game, but before these comes quick brain work.
“Next to a speedy head come swift hands
and feet to the order of importance. There
is no use figuring out an offensive charge if
the legs can’t carry you swiftly into it, if th«
hands can’t guide your stick swiftly through
to completion. You may be skating furiously
down the tee. but your hands guiding the stick
